cluster_relations.rel_desc: The properties of black holes characterize what black holes are like.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Includes: formation-related features and observable effects

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The star life cycle refers to the evolutionary progression of a massive star.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: from formation to end of life

remarks: Star type is not explicitly restated; mapping to massive star is inferred.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The size of black holes is typically quantified using the Schwarzschild radius.
The Schwarzschild radius is defined as the radius where the escape velocity has a specific value.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: escape velocity equals the speed of light

remarks: Condition further refined in next relation to specify equality with speed of light.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Schwarzschild radius is the characteristic radius associated with a black hole beyond which escape is impossible.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: where escape velocity equals the speed of light
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: BoundaryType: effective outer boundary of the black hole

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Classical general relativity describes the black hole singularity as a point of infinite density and curvature.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DescriptionDetails: point of infinite density and curvature

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The description of black holes is an account or model that characterizes black holes.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CompletenessAspect: degree of completeness of description

remarks: This relation is somewhat intrinsic to the 'description of black holes' entity but kept to anchor later relations.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject provides a description, account, or characterization of the object (typically a phenomenon or entity).
args.justification: In both relations, the subject is an informational/attribute entity ('properties of black holes', 'description of black holes') that conceptually provides a description or characterization of the object ('black holes'), so they share the same descriptive predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject describes or represents the temporal evolution or life cycle of the object.
args.justification: The 'star life cycle' entity explicitly refers to the evolutionary progression of a massive star, so a predicate that encodes description of evolution/life cycle is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject quantity is operationally measured or quantified using the object measure, scale, or parameter.
args.justification: The 'size of black holes' is quantified using the 'Schwarzschild radius'; semantically this is a standard measurement pattern where a quantity is measured by a specific metric.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject concept is defined in terms of, or via, the object condition or defining relation.
args.justification: The relation states how the Schwarzschild radius is defined (via a specific escape-velocity condition), so a definitional predicate linking a concept to its defining condition is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject radius is the characteristic or defining radius associated with the object, often marking a physical or conceptual boundary.
args.justification: The Schwarzschild radius is described as the characteristic radius of the black hole, marking the boundary beyond which escape is impossible; a more specific predicate than a generic 'characterizes' improves schema precision.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject (typically a theory or model) describes or represents the object as having certain specified properties or nature.
args.justification: Classical general relativity is explicitly said to describe the black hole singularity as a point of infinite density and curvature; a predicate capturing a theory's characterization of an object is appropriate.

All these relations link descriptive or theoretical constructs (properties, descriptions, life cycles, or theories) to the phenomena they represent; they form a coherent class of representation/description-type relations.

Both relations involve quantitative characterization of black holes: one explicitly states that size is measured by Schwarzschild radius, and the other relates the Schwarzschild radius as the characteristic radius of a black hole; both are best grouped as measurement/parameter relations.
This relation ties the Schwarzschild radius to the escape-velocity condition that defines it, which is prototypically a definitional link between a concept and its defining criterion.
These links concern how entities are described, modeled, or characterized by informational or theoretical constructs, fitting a broad representation/description dimension.
Both relations deal with quantitative characterization using the Schwarzschild radius, which is a measurement-like construct; assigning them to a MEASUREMENT group reflects this semantic dimension.

A definitional relation linking a concept (Schwarzschild radius) to its defining condition is primarily about intensional identity—what the concept is by definition—so an IDENTITY-oriented group is appropriate.
